hey thanks Caitlin and so to give an
overview of some of the enhancements that came in 1:14 we saw 31 total
enhancements that were tracked during the 114 cycle 10 of those enhancements
were stable and it's worth noting that 114 saw the most number of stable
enhancements in a kubernetes released to date we also had 12 that were graduating
to beta and then we had nine introduced as alpha features and I'm excited to
share a couple of the stable enhancements and one of the beta ones in
the highlight section so first up we've got the updated plugin mechanism for

their own tube cuddle sub commands and
we can go to the next slide Kaitlin and
another additional coop cuddle related enhancement is integrating customized
into coop cuddle so again helping with some more user-friendly extensible

users to access to cuddle commands this will help with some many long-standing
issues that users have been facing and so it's really exciting to see both of these two features go ga4 cuttle and
then next all right we have pod readiness gate another enhancement
that builds on the theme of extensibility pod readiness gates are allowing external feedback to be
injected into pod status to help users understand when their pods are ready to
serve traffic these additional indicators can help a limit service
disruption and any other reasons why
your pods could go down if they weren't ready to serve traffic next we have hid
limiting so this new feature will allow process IDs also known as heads to have
more isolation so we have pod - pod isolation and node - pod isolation and
this will help prevent pet exhaustion hitting hid resource targets is a fairly
easy thing to do and doing so can often lead to instability so having this
feature or this enhancement will ensure that kids have a limited impact to other workloads next we've got adding in pod
priority and preemption another feature again building on extensibility here in
kubernetes 114 this is enabling users to set pod priority relative to other pods
so indicating what pods are higher priority and should be scheduled ahead of lower priority pods and this will
also enable or this will also help if your resources making sure that lower
priority pods are removed to allow for higher priority pods to run and the last
feature we wanted to cover the last enhancement added that we want to call it as a highlight is hardening the
defaults are back discovery cluster bindings this enhancement was in response to a
CBE that came out late in November a few of you might be familiar with it 2018 -
120 105 and this is building on the
security posture for kubernetes by removing the discovery from the set of
api's which allow an authenticated access by default so another great
enhancement to bring in to help improve overall security posture for folks using
kubernetes and with that I would like to pass it off to Michelle who's going to
go more deep into details with persistent local volumes right thanks
Claire yeah my name is Michelle I am a member of SIG's storage and I was the
primary leader for the local persistent volumes feature next slide so to give an
overview of the feature what it does is it lets you specify direct-attached
disks as a persistent volume and then you can use them in your pods with the
same persistent volume claim interface that you already use for persistent
volumes in kubernetes so as simple as this sounds this was actually not really
easy to do before we implemented this feature kubernetes previously mainly
supported remote storage systems like a cloud provider providers remote block
storage service or network file systems like NFS and as a result of that many of
the kubernetes components assumed that storage is equally accessible from any
node in the cluster so if before we had
this feature if users actually wanted to use local disks they would have to
manually track and manage the local discs themselves and manually scheduled our pods to
specific nodes and in some cases they would have to write custom schedulers
for their application that had to do this you know environment specific disk
management so the as part of this feature we really wanted to simplify
that use case and make it easier for for
users to be able to use these disks and have first-class knowledge of local
disks in the kubernetes components so one of the big features that we added
was to add extra intelligence into the kubernetes scheduler so that it could
recognize that some persistent volumes may actually not be globally accessible
and are actually restricted to specific nodes in the cluster so now if you use a
local volume in your pod it will always be scheduled to the node where that disk
is located on and when we're initially choosing a persistent volume for your
claim we will take into account what nodes have available local volumes and
we'll also consider any other scheduling constraints that your pod might have
such as CPU or memory requirements node selectors pod affinity or anti affinity
and so on so by adding first-class
support for this feature into the course scheduler we've eliminated the need for
users to write custom schedulers and it can also easily integrate with any other
future feature added to the course scheduler so in terms of the application
workloads that we're targeting for this feature our primary use case is high
performance distributed databases that are deployed using state sets or an operator these workloads can
benefit from getting direct access to local discs in order to get a higher
performance and lower cost but there are trade-offs of lower availability and no
redundancy at the storage layer layer next slide so that's that brings me to
the caveats of this feature local persistent volumes is not designed to be
a general-purpose storage solution there are definitely many trade-offs that you
need to consider if you want to use this feature the biggest trade-off in my
opinion is that your pod becomes inflexible with respect to scheduling in
turn that makes it more prone to data unavailability and even data loss
once your pod uses a local volume it's bound to that node forever and it can
only be scheduled to that node so if that node or disk fails then your pod is
also stuck since it's bound to the volume that's bound to the node so to
deal with this at your application layer you will need to implement data
redundancy and also have a frequent backup plan
to store your critical data in a more reliable storage back-end in addition
you'll need to put into place good monitoring and alerting processes so
that you can be notified of any of these failure conditions and if you want to
automate the recovery process you may also need to build those steps into an
operator one more aspect that you need to pay careful attention to are node
upgrades you have to make sure that your which nodes you upgrade are carefully
ordered and coordinated so that you don't bring end up bringing your application below quorum and
especially in cloud environments where local disks are not actually persistent
you will need to migrate or replicate your data to the new nodes if you're
also planning on running the workloads that use local volumes with other
workloads in your cluster I would also recommend that you also that you use the
pod priority and preemption feature which also went GA in 1:14 this allows
you to give your pods that use local volumes a higher priority so that lower
priority pods can be kicked out to make room for them and in addition other
notable kubernetes features such as dynamic provisioning and node auto
scaling are not integrated with local persistent volumes either which means
that you'll have to do some more capacity planning and allocation especially if you're in on-premise
environment so definitely there are quite a few major trade-offs with this
feature and for that reason local persistent volumes are not a general
purpose solution that you can apply to all your applications they're really
best suited for those workloads that already handle data redundancy at the
application layer and can tolerate data unavailability and loss also given all
the extra steps needed for capacity allocation and failure recovery I've
seen that the most successful users of this feature end up using it for
large-scale data services that already has dead a dedicated ops team that's
able to manage and support it next slide now that being said interest
and adoption of this feature has been very strong since the beginning when we
first designed this two years ago we got a lot of great alpha and beta testers
who actually used the feature in production both in cloud environments
and also on-premise environments and at large scale in some cases I've seen
people use the feature with clusters over a thousand nodes and over 10,000
local persistent volumes so being able
to run at this scale definitely helped uncover many race conditions race
conditions that we had in the scheduler we even had to redesign part of the feature at some point to deal to be able
to handle the scale but I'm really glad to say that after all of this all of our
scale testing and beta testers we really have the confidence to promote this
feature to GA in 114 all right next
slide so now I want to shift topics a
little bit and talk about how you can actually use this feature from a
perspective of a kubernetes user this part is really simple it uses the same
persistent volume clean interface that you already use for remote persistent
volume types in kubernetes the only difference here is that you need to specify a different storage class that
you that you've defined to represent your local disks this API gives you
application portability you can take the same the same application pod spec and
the persistent volume claim spec and deploy it on another cluster and/or
another environment you can easily swap out the storage
class to try out multiple storage backends or if you have a multi cluster
management layer your cluster admin can provide storage classes all with the
same name so that you can even just you know use the same exact persistent
volume claim with the same storage class across all your different clusters and environments so our our main goal with
respect to the user interface is to try to keep it as simple and familiar as
possible so that we can give this portable and consistent API experience
so all the actual magic of the feature in the in the scheduler and in the
storage layer actually happens below the below the user api's so if we go on to
the next slide here in our admin api's
this is where we can start providing that storage provider specific and
environment specific details so as a kubernetes admin what you would do is to
create a storage class and also and enable the intelligent scheduling logic
that we've built in this is what the volume binding mode wait for first
consumer setting does it tells kubernetes that the initial volume
binding of a persistent volume claim should be processed by the scheduler and
it should also wait until there's a pod that actually needs to use it all right
nextslide so that's enabling the storage
class and now moving on we have to deal
with creation of the persistent volume objects themselves this is probably the
most complicated part of the feature and this is something that the cluster
administrator needs to handle before applications can start using the local
persistent volumes so like I said earlier dynamic provisioning is not
supported at the moment so disk allocation and management is more
involved with local volumes than most other cloud storage solutions that sort
of just work out of the box for local volumes you kind of need to be your own
cloud provider that being said we've tried to develop some tools and external
controllers that can help automate some of this process so I have a diagram here
of a typical life cycle of a local disk when you're using it with this feature
first it is made available to kubernetes once that's available then kubernetes
workloads can consume it through the persistent volume claims and then when
the workload is done with that volume and doesn't need it anymore it releases it and then we end up
putting cleaning up that disk and putting it back into the kubernetes pool
next slide going into some more detail let's start with how to make the disk
available to kubernetes this step really depends on your environment and what
workloads you want to support depending on your workload requirements you may
want to do things like partition to disks or raid the disks
some providers like like gke may already automate some of these steps for you but
if you are sort of managing kubernetes on your own then this is definitely
easier to automate if you can make your machine types and your local disk layouts fixed and well-defined without
too many variations between machine types so once you determine how you want
to prepare the disks then you need to link them into a dedicated directory for
every storage class you want to offer in your cluster next slide so once this is
done then this is where our external controller comes in we've developed a
controller that we've called the local volume static provisioner it is
different it's very important to note this is different from a dynamic provisioner and that it doesn't actually
carve out persistent volumes on demand instead what it does is it collects and
manages the inventory of local discs that you've prepared in the previous step and then pre create the persistent
volume objects for them so once the disk is made available to the static provisioner then it handles the rest of
the disk and volume management lifecycle from their application pods will it
creates the Peavey's for every local disk which then the application pods can
request using the persistent volume claims when the claim ends up being
released then the controller handles cleaning up all the data on that disk deleting the persistent volume object
and then creating a brand new persistent volume for it this continues in a cycle
until you finally need to decommission the disk and take it out of service next
so I know that was a lot of information and you can see that while the feature
itself is stable and being run at scale the setup and recovery handling are
still very involved and non-trivial processes so improving these aspects is
the focus of the next phase of the project and we could definitely use help in this area we're looking for folks
that can take ownership for each of these different tasks design and help
drive a solution so if you're interested please reach out to me or join one of

again I'm available with via slack or github to help answer any other questions you may have thank you so much
